_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES



Blanchard Terminal Company LLC (Blanchard [a subsidiary of Marathon Petroleum Corporation]) - Charlotte East Terminal is a refined petroleum products distributor. The Charlotte East Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Charlotte, NC. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.



Blanchard - Charlotte East Terminal in Charlotte, NC is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Blanchard believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.



The Charlotte East Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. Blanchard promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection along with RC 14001 process management program. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Blanchard has designed and implemented, including:



A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;

B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;

C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;

D. An overview of the emergency response program; and

E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.



A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The primary function of the Charlotte East Terminal is to a

ct as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with liquefied petroleum gas, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions when handling liquefied petroleum gas to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community along with the surrounding environment. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which liquefied petroleum gas is handled as well as the various safety/control devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, contractors, and haulers which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Charlotte East Terminal.



The facility maintains fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored (under pressure) in one (1) storage vessel. The butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the on-site gasoline truck-loading rack. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point (<250 degrees Fahrenheit) fusible elements, fail safe control valves, vessel multi-port pressure relief valves, fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shutoff devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal (pressure) reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Charlotte East Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.



B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC

PREVENTION MEASURES



Blanchard's accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning and response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by our regulated substances to its employees, the public, and t

he environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29 CFR 1910.119. Enforcement of 40 CFR Part 68 is delegated to Mecklenburg County. The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the Charlotte East Terminal:



1) Employee Participation,

2) Process Safety Information,

3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA),

4) Standard Operating Procedures,

5) Operator/Contractor Training,

6) Contractor Safety,

7) Pre-startup Safety Review,

8) Mechanical Integrity with Preventive Maintenance,

9) Hazardous Work Permits,

10) Management of Change,

11) Incident Investigation procedures/reporting,

12) Emergency Response Action Plans,

13) Compliance Audits and

14) Trade Secrets.



These fourteen (14) individual elements of the Facility prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. The Blanchard Terminal Company and its employees are committed to the standards required by these management programs. In addition to the above elements, the Terminal has specific prevention measures that are employed as part of its operating procedures and engineering and administrative controls to help quickly detect, contain/control, and minimize the consequences of a release. These are briefly summarized as follows:



General Risk Reduction and Safety Measures include:



-Engineering and construction in accordance with Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practice and company standards;

-Equipment properly designed with protection from overpressure (pressure safety relief valves, etc.);

-Updated technical drawings, Piping & Instrument Diagrams and Process Flow Diagrams;

-Operating systems monitored (real time) and controlled by trained Operators along with 24/7 remote monitoring;

-Computerized monitoring (real time) and control of process operation;

-Redundant control systems with uninterruptable power supply (UPS) back-up;

-Automatic a

s that occur at our facility. The Blanchard Terminal Company requires that all significant (or potentially significant releases) undergo a root cause analysis (Tap Root). There have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials covered under the EPA RMP regulation.



D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Response actions are coordinated/reviewed/exercised with the Charlotte Fire Department. An FRP/ERAP ("Smart Plan") is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire and/or to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.





E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Blanchard is continually striving to make the Charlotte East Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.



In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Blanchard looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements. In addition, Blanchard Terminal Company is a RC 14001 company who follows API 754 practices relative to the reporting, tracking, and evaluation of leading/lagging indicators to identify opportunities for continual improvement. Currently, additional efforts are underway to improve the existing MOC/PSSR procedures.
